contextId.occurrenceNote: The terms "grace" and "peace" are metonyms for the person who acts toward people in a kindly and peaceful manner. Alternate translation: "May God be kind to you and give you peace" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: May grace and peace be to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Word" here is a metonym for "message." Alternate translation: "the Lord's teachings" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

The abstract noun "reception" can be expressed as the verb "receive" or "welcome." Alternate translation: "how warmly you received us" or "how warmly you welcomed us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: what kind of reception we had among you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "hearts" is a metonym for a person's desires and thoughts. Alternate translation: "who knows our desires and thoughts" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
"Word" here is a metonym for "message." Alternate translation: "you accepted it ... as it truly is, the message that comes from God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quote: ἐδέξασθε ... καθὼς ἀληθῶς ἐστὶν, λόγον Θεοῦ
contextId.glQuote: you accepted it ... as it truly is, the word of God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "heart" represents thoughts and emotions. Though Paul and those traveling with him were not present physically in Thessalonica, they continued to care and think about the believers there. Alternate translation: "in person, but we continued to think about you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
By "hope" Paul means the assurance he has that God will reward him for his work. The Thessalonian Christians are the reason for his hope. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quote: ἡμῶν ἐλπὶς ... ἢ οὐχὶ καὶ ὑμεῖς
contextId.glQuote: our hope ... Is it not you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Thessalonians are the reason for his joy. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Here "crown" refers to a laurel wreath awarded to victorious athletes. The expression "crown of pride" means a reward for victory, or having done well. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here "heart" is a metonym for one's beliefs and convictions. Alternate translation: "strenghten you, so that you will be" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quote: τὸ στηρίξαι ὑμῶν τὰς καρδίας, ἀμέμπτους
contextId.glQuote: strengthen your hearts, so that they will be

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Word" here is a metonym for "message." Alternate translation: "by means of understanding the teachings of the Lord" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: by the word of the Lord
